Trial_Design.evidence: This retrospective observational study was conducted at the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital, Queensland, Australia, from 2016 to 2018.

Participants.evidence: A total of 2129 surgical patients receiving blood transfusion were included: ICS only (n = 115), allogeneic red blood cells (RBCs) only (n = 1944), or RBCs and ICS (n = 70).

Intervention.evidence: ICS only (n = 115), allogeneic red blood cells (RBCs) only (n = 1944), or RBCs and ICS (n = 70).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the cost implications associated with perioperative adverse outcomes following allogeneic blood transfusion (ABT) and intraoperative cell salvage (ICS) in surgical patients.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 2129 surgical patients receiving blood transfusion were included: ICS only (n = 115), allogeneic red blood cells (RBCs) only (n = 1944), or RBCs and ICS (n = 70).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Most adverse outcomes (≥3) occurred following RBCs and ICS (37.1%), followed by RBCs (23.7%) and ICS (16.5%).

Harms.evidence: Most adverse outcomes (≥3) occurred following RBCs and ICS (37.1%), followed by RBCs (23.7%) and ICS (16.5%).
